At these high thresholds, the majority of known cases tended to become grouped into a single large cluster, thereby homogenizing any individual-level variation that could be used by the weighted model to predict the distribution of new cases. also leads to a reduction of case coverage as shown in Fig. 3. At the respective optimal thresholds, less than half of new cases were adjacent to clusters of known cases (38.2% for Seattle, 49.1% for Northern Alberta, and 41.8% for Tennessee).
